channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Executives Are Jailed in Chile Finance Scandal
item.description: Four executives of one of Chile’s largest financial groups, a tax auditor and a former government official were taken into custody in a case that has shaken the economic elite and the main opposition party.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Two Are Charged in Killing of Boris Y. Nemtsov
item.description: A police officer who fought Islamic insurgents and a security guard were charged in Moscow in connection with the killing of the Kremlin critic, while three other suspects were jailed.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Zaur Dadayev, arrested in the slaying of the Russian opposition figure Boris Nemtsov, looks out from a defendants’ cage inside a court building in Moscow on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Not There’ Campaign Removes Women From Ads for International Women’s Day
item.description: A project by the Clinton Foundation modified public advertisements to raise awareness of its No Ceilings initiative on the status of women and girls worldwide.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: 22 Arrested in Beating Death of Rape Suspect in India
item.description: Photographs and videos on social media of an enraged mob that seized the man from a jail, dragged him through the streets and beat him to death helped lead to the arrests, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Obama Says Nuclear Deal Offered to Iran Is ‘Extraordinarily Reasonable’
item.description: In an interview aired on Sunday, President Obama said the deal will test whether Iran’s leadership is serious about at last resolving the dispute over its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry at a meeting in Paris on Saturday. Mr. Kerry spent much of the last week in Europe and the Middle East consulting with allies.

item.title: Missing Malaysian Airliner’s Crew Behaved Normally, Report Says
item.description: The captain and co-pilot of Flight 370, which disappeared a year ago, had shown no signs of distress, a Malaysian government report said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: China Detains Women’s Rights Activists in Several Cities
item.description: Officials were apparently trying to forestall a campaign against sexual harassment on public transportation coinciding with International Women’s Day.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Black Comedians in South Africa Put Power in the Punch Lines
item.description: A thriving comedy scene is provocatively stretching the limits of what can be laughed at in the post-apartheid era.
item.dc:creator: BAZ DREISINGER
item.media:description: Loyiso Gola during comedy night at The Orbit, a Johannesburg club.

item.title: African Training Exercise Turns Urgent as Threats Grow
item.description: New ties between Boko Haram and the Islamic State have reinforced American and European concerns that have led to the training of African troops.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The Chadian army trained with American Special Forces during the annual Exercise Flintlock in the Sahara Desert.

item.title: With Misattributed Constable Masterpiece, a Rare Look Into the Imprecise World of Art Identification
item.description: At a time when the attribution of paintings can be so litigious, a startling reassessment provides a rare window into the often imprecise, and debate-riddled, field of identifying the authorship of artworks.
item.dc:creator: LORNE MANLY
item.media:description: John Constable’s “Salisbury Cathedral From the Meadows” sold for 1,000 times as much after it was deemed authentic.

item.title: Back in Afghanistan, Modern Romeo and Juliet Face Grave Risks
item.description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali had faced criminal charges and death threats after eloping and fleeing their village in the high mountains of central Afghanistan last year.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohammad Ali resting while preparing soil for a potato crop near his family home outside the town of Bamian in Afghanistan. He carries a pistol for protection.

item.title: Boko Haram Generates Uncertainty With Pledge of Allegiance to Islamic State
item.description: The Nigerian terrorist group appeared to make a spiritually binding oath to follow the authority of the Islamic State, but experts said the practical significance of the move was unclear.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Jihadists May Have Wrecked an Ancient Iraqi Site
item.description: Iraqi officials are investigating reports that the Islamic State destroyed Hatra, an archaeological site dating to the first century B.C., two days after confirming that it bulldozed an ancient Assyrian city.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A temple in Hatra, a site from the first century B.C. that the Islamic State reportedly destroyed.

item.title: Egypt Executes an Islamist Supporter of Ousted President
item.description: Egypt’s government carried out the death penalty against a man convicted of murder during the political violence that followed the military takeover of the government in 2013, the Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Foreign Workers Missing After Militants Attack Libyan Oil Field
item.description: About 10 foreigners were missing after an attack on a Libyan oil field, and it is possible they had been taken hostage, the Czech Republic’s foreign minister said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: What Iran Won’t Say About the Bomb
item.description: Should it have to say how much it knows about bomb design?
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: After Talks, Nuclear Deal on Iran Is Seen as Close
item.description: With an end-of-March deadline for drafting the outline of a potential agreement, Secretary of State John Kerry faces an array of challenges in completing an initial accord and defending it to Congress.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Move Over Mao: Beloved ‘Papa Xi’ Awes China
item.description: Not since Mao Zedong dominated the nation with his masterly blend of populism, fervor and fear has a Chinese leader commanded as much public awe as President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trinkets depicting President Xi Jinping and Mao Zedong. Not since Mao has a Chinese leader commanded such public awe.

item.title: Gunman Kills Five in Restaurant in Mali
item.description: A ranking security official said Saturday morning that two people had been arrested in connection with the attack, for which a group of extremists are said to have claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Police officers blocked the street near La Terrasse restaurant in Bamako, Mali, on Saturday, after five people were shot dead overnight there in a suspected terrorist attack.

item.title: 2 Suspects Are Detained in Killing of Kremlin Critic
item.description: The director of Russia’s Federal Security Service named two men as suspects in the brazen shooting of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov in Moscow on Feb. 27, but questions remained over who orchestrated the killing.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Mourners on Saturday at the site where the Russian opposition figure Boris Y. Nemtsov was shot and killed in February in Moscow.
